posts.name: Ved
posts.cooked:
Hi there, I’m a member of team 1477 and have been working on a configurable round tube elevator design over the past month. The design is inspired by the 148 2018 round tube elevator. I would appreciate any feedback/questions on the design.

image 755×1212 125 KB image 785×1110 118 KB

image 755×1212 125 KB

image 755×1212 125 KB

image 785×1110 118 KB

image 785×1110 118 KB

Design Goals:

Continuous Rigging

Capstan Gearbox

Constructed from (mostly) plate and tube

Configurable amount of stages (1+)

Lightweight

Quick Facts :

Compressed Height: 37 in.

Extended Height: 84 in.

Total weight: 13.55 Lbs

Stages: The stages of the elevator consist of a “stage cap” and “stage plug” which contain all the pulleys, rollers, and structural components of each stage (pictured below). The stage cap and stage plug are joined together using two 1.5 OD 1/32 wall tubes.

Stage cap: image 989×473 61.3 KB A stage cap consists of two bearing block assemblies, a 1.5 OD 1/32 wall tube, and two 3/8 Aluminum Gussets connecting the bearing block assemblies and cross tube together.

image 989×473 61.3 KB

image 989×473 61.3 KB

Cross section of a bearing block assembly:

image 796×828 79.8 KB

image 796×828 79.8 KB

image 796×828 79.8 KB

Each bearing block assembly contains two 1x1 WCP tube plugs in a 3dp sleeve and a billet block underneath. The components are tied together using two .09 Al gussets, which also hold the roller bearing.

Stage Plug: image 828×493 53.2 KB Each stage plug contains the same bearing block assembly as the stage cap (but upsidedown), and uses 1.5 x1.5 tube for the main structure. The stage plugs also have tiny “wings” that contact hardstops on the upright round tubes to maintain proper overlap between stages.

image 828×493 53.2 KB

image 828×493 53.2 KB

Roller Bearing The hardest part of this elevator was designing the roller bearings. The intent for this roller bearing design was to capture as much of the tube as possible while still keeping the gap between the stages low. Currently this design captures approx 35% of the tube face and allows for a .25 in. gap between stages.

The main roller bearing body is 3d printed, and has a .25 OD .201 ID shaft pressed into to strengthen the part. The roller bearing also has a .5 OD .188 ID bearing to support the radial load and a needle roller bearing to support axial loads. Although this design is meant to be 3d printed, we have a 4th axis on our OMIO X8 and will most likely machine it out of delrin if possible.

image 784×660 81.5 KB image 733×655 40.6 KB

image 784×660 81.5 KB

image 784×660 81.5 KB

image 733×655 40.6 KB

image 733×655 40.6 KB

Rigging: Elevator has continuous rigging, with the ropes hidden behind the 1.5 round tube uprights. The rope starts at the top of the carriage, runs through the pulleys & the capstan gearbox, and terminates at the bottom of the carriage. A 1/2 hex shaft connected to a ratchet wrench on the top of the carriage tensions the rope to remove any slack.

Capstan Gearbox: image 1349×806 154 KB image 1304×901 161 KB image 1172×618 95.8 KB

image 1349×806 154 KB

image 1349×806 154 KB

image 1304×901 161 KB

image 1304×901 161 KB

image 1172×618 95.8 KB

image 1172×618 95.8 KB

The capstan gearbox is different from a conventional elevator spool system in that it uses the friction between the rope & capstan (black thing with ridges) to cause the rope to move along, rather than spooling and unspooling the rope.

Benefits of the capstan gearbox are:

Capstan diameter can be much smaller than a standard elevator rope spool

No spooling string means no dealing with issues regarding variable fleet angles and rope spooling on top of itself

Smaller diameter capstans allow for a lower gear reduction, saving weight

The capstan gearbox in this pic is integrated into the 2x1 base tube, which allows it to neatly tuck underneath the elevator. Currently there is 1 Neo geared 3:1 to power the system, but the gearbox can accept up to 2 motors and any of the COTS planetary gearboxes.

link_counts.title: Capstan Drive - Lightweight, Low Backlash Position Control

posts.name: Justus
posts.cooked: Lighter weight. Tubes could also be carbon fiber for even less weight.

posts.name: Ved
posts.cooked:
Sure! I updated the post to include more info about the whole elevator, including the capstan gearbox. Accidentally fat fingered Ctrl - Enter when making the post making it sent way early. The second half of this article describes the capstan equation in an easy to understand manner:

I fell in love with cable driven mechanisms a few years ago and put together some of my first mechanical tentacles to celebrate. But only after playing with them did I start to understand the princ…

I have a video of a capstan gearbox we prototyped that demonstrates how this specific setup works. Ill find it and send it when I get the chance.

link_counts.title: Cable Mechanism Maths: Designing Against The Capstan Equation | Hackaday

posts.name: Graeme McDaniel
posts.cooked: My question for you is why did you choose to go with such a high-diameter tube.

posts.name: Ved
posts.cooked:
We are using .035 wall 1.5 OD round tube, which is lighter per foot than current COTS 2x1 extrusion.

This does make the elevator weaker than a standard 2x1 elevator, so it can’t be used in high load situations, but is perfect light loads (such as lifting game pieces).

If we do end up needing to climb with the elevator in 2023, we have a configurable capstan driven rectangle tube elevator cadded and ready to use. image 828×1792 83.1 KB

image 828×1792 83.1 KB

image 828×1792 83.1 KB

posts.name: Ved
posts.cooked: Tube OD was based on strength and what others had teams had previously built. 1.5 OD is proven to work by 148 in 2018 and 1619 in 2019 (iirc).

posts.cooked:
Vedante:

image 1172×618 95.8 KB

image 1172×618 95.8 KB

image 1172×618 95.8 KB

The capstan gearbox is different from a conventional elevator spool system in that it uses the friction between the rope & capstan (black thing with ridges) to cause the rope to move along, rather than spooling and unspooling the rope.

Clever design choice.  I’ve been unsatisfied with spool-type systems in the past.

How do the two lines route through the capstans themselves?

posts.name: Ved
posts.cooked: Here are the CAD files for both the round tube elevator and our rectangle tube elevator: Round tube Rectangle tube

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
On the roller, I’d suggest relieving the middle of the hourglass just a bit so it doesn’t contact during normal operation.  The differential slipping between the large diameter of the hourglass and the small diameter will add some friction.

I like the thrust bearing idea!  You should consider adding metal race washers on both sides of it if you are expecting real loads.  Even Aluminum washers would be an improvement.  And grease that sucker!  And capstans are awesome!
